headline: Slow Cooker Beer Pulled Pork
description: This Sweet Baby Ray's pulled pork is an easy, big-batch recipe for your slow cooker. Serve it with soft buns for the best pulled pork sandwiches ever!

video.description: Check out this simple, yet tasty slow cooker pork.
video.name: Slow Cooker Beer Pulled Pork

name: Slow Cooker Beer Pulled Pork
recipeIngredient: 1 (12 fluid ounce) can beer (such as Shiner® Bock)
1 (12 ounce) bottle barbecue sauce (such as Sweet Baby Ray's®)

recipeInstructions.text: Place pork into the slow cooker. Season with salt, pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder. Pour beer into the bottom of the slow cooker. Cover and cook on High for 1 hour. Reduce the heat to Low and cook until meat is tender and can be easily pulled apart with a fork, 8 to 10 hours.
Remove pork from the slow cooker and shred with two forks. Discard cooking juices. Return shredded pork to the slow cooker and stir in barbecue sauce. Cover and cook on Medium for 1 hour.

review.reviewBody: I happened to have a +3 lb. pork "shoulder" roast (lots of marbeling and large fat cap) so was perfect for this recipe. NOTE: butcher says the shoulder & butt pork roast come from the same area of the pig's shoulder. Because it wasn't the 5 lb. used in the recipe I made some minimal alterations in amounts and time. This was wonderful and pull-apart tender. We both highly recommend it!!
I’ve made this many times. It’s so easy, good and EVERYONE loves it. Thank you for the recipe.

This turned out to be excellent. I tasted the pork as I was shredding it and it did not have much flavor so I was concerned. But then I added 1 part Famous Dave's Devil's Spit and 2 parts Famous Dave's Sweet and Zesty Barbecue Sauce and it came alive! It even had a smoky flavor to it. I swear by these two sauces. I will definitely make this again.

We love this easy pulled pork recipe and have made it several times. I do not discard the flavorful drippings, I use it to make rice. The drippings are measured out, some of the fat skimmed off, and brought to a boil on the stove. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Since rice is a 1:2 ration with water, I reduce the rice by one cup, bring to a boil, and simmer for 20 minutes. Best rice to have with pulled pork!

Apparently my slow cooker doesn't have a medium setting, only high/ low/ warm... so my only improvision was that after the bbq sauce was added, I put it on high for 30 min instead of medium for an hour. Turned out delicious. Gonna make some killer work lunches.

Oh my goodness! I have a new favorite way to make pulled pork sandwiches. We loved the beer flavor! I rubbed the spices into the pork shoulder, browned it on all sides, then put it in the crockpot with the beer and more garlic and onion powder. I didn’t have any shiner bock so used a can of 805. Crocked on low for 8 hours, removed, shredded, put 1/2 the meat in the freezer and returned 1/2 to the crockpot with 1/2 a jar of Buddy Stubbs sweet heat and crocked on low for 1 hour. In the mean time, I made a batch of Chef John’s Hamburger Buns. When serving, I added a few tbsp of bbq sauce to each sandwich. It got rave reviews at our Super Bowl party (for 2...there’s a pandemic). Can’t wait for leftovers tomorrow!

Very good, I'll be making pork butt this way forever. Also, it's very forgiving. I had to use a 7+ pound roast, because that was the smallest one they had. I didn't know it had a bone in it, and it filled the cooker so much I couldn't use the whole bottle of beer. It was still wonderful. South Carolina has 4 kinds of BBQ sauce depending on your region (Catsup based, mustard, vinegar, and tomato). I used the vinegar based one--still wonderful. I bet if I added some liquid smoke, it would probably fool some people as the traditional outdoor deal. Be sure you use a dark beer.
Best pulled pork recipe
I love the beer flavor this slow cooker recipe brought to the pork. Very simple ingredients and perfect for a party!
Used a Guinness for the beer and added

This will be my new go to pulled pork recipe. I had an 8lb pork butt roast so I added extra spices accordingly. I only did the one bottle of beer. It was plenty. I used Yuengling Lager beer. I may have used less than 12 oz of BBQ sauce. I don't like too much. I had three different kinds of bbq sauces leftover so I just mixed them together. I did put a little of the juices back in too. Cooked for 1 hr on high and 8 on low, then 1/2 hr on warm. Served on ciabatta rolls with home made coleslaw, and green beans. Whole family loved it! Very easy and delicious!!
So good and soooo easy! I will make this often!

I've made several variations of this for my wife and we love it! I've always used Jan's suggestion and added several additional spices to taste. Bay leaf, paprika, dried mustard....whatever you want. I also throw in a touch more spices than what's called for. I save the juices and add a little flour for gravy in a side pan. Can use it for au jus dipping as is. I used Yuengling larger beer if your east of the Mississippi! If you're on the West side, no luck. Maybe special order?

Absolutely delicious!! I used more seasonings than suggested plus I used the only beer (Blue Moon) I had....truly wonderful!! I also added the juice and drippings to my favorite bbq sauce and simmered for 30mins. Thanks for sharing!

This is very easy. It doesn't have the smoky flavor of being smoked/grilled, but it is very moist. I cooked mine overnight since I am gone longer than the cooking time and even with the warming setting on my slow cooker, things tend to dry out if left there. So we re-heated after coming home from work and had delicious pulled pork sandwiches!
Very good. I used onion salt and omitted the regular salt.

I used this rib rub on the pork All Recipes Dry Rub for Ribs 
to give it flavor and then let my family choose which BBQ sauce they wanted to add. 
My slow cooker runs a bit hot so it was done after 5-6 hours on low. I wouldn't let this go overnight since I'm afraid it would dry out.
It was so easy to make and it was delicious
Sliced onions on bottom; added beer and few drops liquid smoke, removed most of the drippings and added 2 Tbsp brown sugar and hefty spoonful of cayenne with BBq sauce; amazing!!!!!!!!!

I made it last night. followed the recipe. it was just alright. before adding the sauce I tried a couple pieces. not much of a taste, kinda plain. after the sauce certainly more flavor. but just alright. probably won't make this recipe again. thanks for sharing though.
Simple and easy!!!!
I have made this recipe at least three times...It's great for a holiday potluck lunch for work, or just some comfort food on a cold night, it's just good at anytime of the year.

I made this for a group Get Together & everyone love it ! I did slow cook it overnight and then reheated 2 hrs before the event. It taste great,but the texture was a little too mushy... Next time, I will slow cooker for 8 hrs and reheat for 1 hour.
Easy and tasty - will make again.

Great recipe, but I followed the suggestion of someone else and added a couple of teaspoons of paprika and a teaspoon of cayenne pepper to the rub and I added a sliced onion and minced garlic to the bottom of the crock pot before placing the pork shoulder into the pot. I also cooked the first two hours on high heat (~400) turning once after one hour. I simply wasn't sure that it would be done in time if I only cooked one hour on high heat. The pork turned out great and my family loved the flavor so much that I couldn't keep their hands out of the shredded meat in order to prep for the next step.
Followed recipe added extra pepper / extra ginger ale soda and split the sauce - froze half the meat and taking it for packed lunches - amazing flavor!
Excellent!!!!
I made 2 crock pots of this and brought it to a Labor Day party for 50 people. Everyone kept telling me how much they loved it! I will make it again for sure!
no changes, will make it again!

I stayed as close to the recipe as I could. I used a 3 1/2 lb pork shoulder (not butt). I decreased cooking time a bit and other ingredients accordingly. I couldn’t find the Shriner Bock so I used a dark Samuel Adams lager. I skimmed/cut fat off before shredding and saved the juice like other reviewers said. I added some of the juice to the barbecue sauce. My company loved it! I would make again but I would try to find a larger piece of meat closer to the recipe as I wish I would have had more leftovers!!
Added a little Chili Powder and used a honey bbq sauce.

I have finally found my go-to pulled pork recipe! I love how easy it is with minimal ingredients, which is my style. I had two bone-in 7 lb pork roasts so I added a half more of everything except the beer. I put them in 2 different crock pots and used a Sam Adams Summer Wheat beer to pour on top, I also added some liquid smoke to give it a bit of a "smoker" taste, nothing too crazy. I started the roasts around 9pm on low and in the morning at 9pm I shredded the meat, drained the liquid and put it to the side to add later if needed (but I didn't end up needing it). I put the crock pot on high for an hour and then on warm with the lid off for a bit. It sat on warm until the party at 6pm. I never did add the bbq sauce so people could add it themselves. Everyone seriously loved it!

This recipe couldn't be easier! I have made this recipe many times and it never disappoints. It's also great to try different sauces. We either eat plain or use onion rolls. Definitely a favorite in our house. Try using different rubs as well instead of different spices to change it up some.
Will definitely make it again. Very simple, very tender. I will probably spice it up some like other reviews have suggested.
Great, just use your favorite barbecue sauce!

This is a great recipe! Be sure to flip the roast over half way through the 8 hour slow cook time, this will help in rendering all of the fat and make for a more even cook. Also, butter and toast the buns before serving and you will love it! If you are a pickle fan, add sliced dill pickles and it is amazing!!!
Very easy recipe to follow and family enjoyed it immensely. Can't wait to make it again.
Everyone loved it. My 4 year old granddaughter had 2 servings!
Visiting family out of state and made this. Easy and turned out delish....will make again for sure
Beer slow cooked pulled pork was incredible and yummy! Thank you. Adding cole slaw just made it even yummier for a great dinner.
Great recipe. Only change I made was to add some liquid smoke.

This is really good with French rolls! I have made this twice with Stone IPA. It came out soooo good both times. I have an 8 qt crock pot so I put 2 cans (bottles) of beer in so the pot is full enough. I think recipe is for 6 qt. I also skip the last hour and just shred the meat, mix in BBQ sauce and heat in microwave for 2 min due to the larger crock pot. This is now a new family favorite!
One of my favorite pulled pork recipes. I follow the recipe as written.
Never measured my qua high of spice. Added ketcup, took extra fat out of sauce. Would definitely make again
I stuck to the recipe pretty much. I added less barbeque sauce (to taste the meat as well). and I lost track of time and cooked for about 10hrs. I will make again and again.
Great taste, I didn’t change anything in the recipe. My family loved it
I have made this recipe many times and the flavor is awesome. I generally use a dark brown ale or lager, because thats the type of beer I like, and it reflects in the taste.
will definitely make again, I use Guinness for the beer.

This is a great, easy recipe. My entire family loves it. I added one bottle of Zatarains Cajun hot sauce. I let the mixture cool just a bit on the warm setting. This let the fat come to the top. I spooned off the fat, then shredded the pork and returned it to the slow cooker. I added a little more BBQ sauce and heated for one hour on low. Turned out great.
Delicious and easy.

Wahoo! I finally found a fabulous Pulled Pork recipe!! I needed this to be gluten free so I made this with Omission Lager Gluten Free and Sweet Baby Ray's Original Barbecue Sauce which is also gluten free. The flavor was terrific! I also froze the extra to use at a later date and it was just as good.
This was a big hit with my family. I even searched for the recommended beer and think that played a big role in the flavor. We will be making this again.

Excellent recipe. I made two pork butts because I was worried I wouldn’t have enough meat. I’m glad that I did, because I had a lot of fat to pick off the meat before putting it back in the crock pot. I spread it out on a cookie sheet and take a small knife to take off fat and membranes left. My family loved it!

This is delicious! I used Masterpiece BBQ sauce and an Oktoberfest beer. I saved some of the juices to add back in for some extra moisture after shredding and cooking for another hour. Put it on a really good roll and you’re good to go.
Loved it!

This was so easy! I'm all about fast prep and little to no thinking when it comes to cooking. I had a pumpkin ale on hand and the flavors of that went soooo well with the seasoning. I was surprised other reviewers said they needed more seasoning, I thought there was plenty (though I think I was a pound short on the meat, so maybe that's why, or perhaps the beer with those added spicy flavors enhanced it), and I even loved it without the bbq sauce, but I was craving bbq, so I just added 1/2 the bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's. That's our fam's favorite! People can add more sauce to taste or enjoy more of the meat and seasonings flavor. This is going in our fave crockpot meals to cook frequently. Very yummy.
Delicious and simple.

Cut the recipe in half because I don't need to make as much at one time. Did not change any ingredients. I used Blue Moon beer because that's what I had on hand the few times I have made it. I am making this recipe again today. My husband loves it. I keep some of the finished product plain, and heat some in Sweet Baby Ray's barbecue sauce. Either way, it's a winner! Thanks for this great slow cooker recipe!
This was delicious! I doubled the recipe and it was fine. I used Fosters lager beer and Sweet Baby Ray’s original bbq sauce. This is a winner!
Yummy !!!! Very good pulled pork.. I made as written.....

It was great made for a family get together . Everyone loved it . Cooked over night about 10 hours fell off the bone and pulled easy . Don’t drink beer bought one 24 oz beer and poured the whole thing in the crock pot . Probably the best pork butt I ever cooked
Loved by all....great as is.

OMGoodness, can you say 'scrump-delicious'?!! I can't even spell that right, this recipe was so good! I only had a bottle of Miller Light, so I used the whole bottle. Otherwise, I didn't change anything from the recipe. I knew the hubby and son would gobble it up, but the real test was my daughter, who ate it all up also - and she's a VERY picky eater! Thanks so much for sharing. This is a keeper!
I used Laguntas beer. Slow cooker for 11 hours. Turned over once, reseasoned. Meat fell off bone but fat separated very well too.
I used Laguntas beer. Slow cooker for 11 hours. Turned over once, reseasoned. Meat fell off bone but fat separated very well too.
Excellent recipe. Simple & don't change a thing.

We all loved it!! I mixed the spices together then rubbed them all over the top of the meat after putting it in the crockpot. I cooked it overnight plus a few hours in the morning. It turned out very tender, juicy, and delicious!
Tasted great. Only changes I made were: had a 8 pound pork butt, doubled the seasoning because of the roast size, and added a few dashes of liquid smoke with the beer.
I made it with a beef roast and it was superb. Kraft brown sugar bbq sauce. Cooked about 10 hrs total, used same ingredients. Definitely make again
Can also use Root Beer instead of regular beer.
This was very good. Reduced the cooking time by an hour since our Pork Roast was only 3 lbs.

This is the best pulled pork I've made. I have made this twice, once with the exact directions listed here and a second time with some minor personal preferences. (type of beer, more garlic, type of bbq sauce) and it was amazing. 

Use the recipe as is or switch up the bbq sauce to your liking. The bbq sauce is where a ton of the flavor comes from, the consistency of the pork has more to do with the ingredients and the cooking. 

Really great recipe thank you!

Awesome and straight to the point! Nothing fancy, just salt, pepper garlic and onion powder and actually one whole white onion chopped and a few diced garlic along with a corona beer! One hour on high and 6 on low. ! Took 10 scoops of the juice and heated on the oven with a half a cup of Sweet Rays! This is a great straight to recipe!
One of the best I’ve had . I had a 15 lb pork butt and had to cook in two crock pots. The result was awesome.
Definitely make again!

Put a 7+ Pound pork butt roast on a bed of thick sliced onion, fat pad up. Followed rest of seasoning directions. Cooked it on high for 2 hours due to its size, then on low for 10 hours. Drained off liquid, shredded in a 10x15 flat glass casserole. I removed fat and bone, added Sweet Baby Rays sauce. Dish was full! I'll make this again!

I LOVE this recipe! I have made this 4 or 5 times exactly as written (I usually use Guinness). My only issue is never being able to find a 5 pound pork butt. I usually get about 3 pounds and then just eyeball the spices, so it’s no big deal. My family consists of just my husband and I so this is dinner for the whole week when we make it. So good!

I have made this numerous times and it is always amazing. After making this recipe I have made 2 changes. I use brown ale because I think the sweetness and flavor work well. I also drain the liquid, separate the fat then simmer the liquid with very little bbq sauce and I find the flavor of the port is way better than just tasting the bbq sauce

I was nervous about using pork tenderloin, as it can be dry, but this pulled pork was outstanding. I used a bottle of Blue Moon and Neumann's Own Honey BBQ sauce. Next time I'll finely chop an onion and add some minced garlic. I put the meat in half thawed and cooked it on low for 9 hours with all the liquid. Easy and delicious!! Thank you!
The pilled pork turned out to be very tender. I enjoyed the taste but my wife found the beer taste to be a bit too strong.

I made this last night for a Halloween potluck and it was Fantastic! I followed the base recipe but made a couple of minor additions: I added some thinly sliced Vidalia onions, 1 tsp of smoked paprika, 1/2 tsp of cayenne and 1/2 tsp liquid smoke. I used A bottle of miller lite and cooked my 3 lb pork loin on low for about 10 hours. All of the liquid was absorbed into the meat making it nice and juicy and the meat was literally falling apart it was so tender. I served it plain with white slider buns with a bottle of sweet baby rays sauce on the side for anyone who wanted to add it to their sandwiches. The additional spices made the plain meat very tasty for those who preferred to withhold the sauce. Thanks for sharing!

My go to for making pulled pork in a slow cooker. I adjust seasonings to add more flavor (coffee grounds, garlic and onion powder, brown sugar, smoked paprika, salt pepper, red pepper flakes, etc). I also use hard cider instead of Beer (recommendation from professional chef friend). All gives such a great flavor to the super tender meat!

I have tried many pulled pork recipes from this site and this is by far my favorite! I adjusted some things to my own taste. I only added a little BBQ sauce and added some liquid smoke and Worcestershire sauce. I'm weird, I don't even like ketchup and rarely use it. I didn't discard the juices. I adjusted the flavor of the juice, strained it and put the meat back in to simmer on low until it was eaten, adding a little more beer to keep it moist. It was truly delicious! I will make this again and again!
I don't even really like BBQ but my family does so I gave this a try. It's a huge hit every time and even I like it. I serve it on buns topped with homemade slaw.

This was wonderful! Made as is, it is just perfect and tender. If you like it a little more sweet and spicy I also added 1/4 c. Honey, 3 Tbsp. Brown Sugar, and 1 tsp. Cayenne pepper to the BBQ sauce. Tasted GREAT! I'll definitely make this again.

Delish! I used a pork loin and a can of Coors Light. I did not throw away the juice as instructed because I wanted to tone down the spiciness of the bbq sauce. I always used root beer but not having any on hand, made this a great find. I will make again. Thanks for sharing!

This came out fantastic! I chopped some cloves of garlic and one red onion to use instead of the onion/garlic powder. I used Shiner for the beer and Stubb's for the BBQ sauce. I will be making this recipe again!
I absolutely LOVE this recipe. I use recipes for almost everything. This is my Go-To for pulled pork. I did take some tips from other reviews, which included adding liquid smoke.
Very good. I would make it again.

This is the second slow cooker pork recipe I have tried and this one was no better than the first. I would not recommend discarding the broth-the pork was quite dry, and adding the barbecue sauce did not moisten the pork enough . I ended up adding a bottle of Not Your Father's root beer to add some flavor and moistness, but t was still just an OK recipe. No one else in my family cared for it and we threw out what was left over. A note to Southerners--this is not close to being as good as anything you get in the South--you will be disappointed if you are used to true siouthern barbecue,.
I made this and have them with haw

07.01.17 ~ Great recipe to use if you are having company and want the meat made a day ahead. I put a pork loin in the crockpot at night before I went to bed. In the morning it was cooked and oh so tender. I didn't add the bbq to the meat after I shredded it as I knew some in our party don't care for it. I served this on mini Hawaiian buns and had different flavors of bbq sauce available and Cole slaw for those of us who like to top pork with the slaw. I am not a beer drinker - at all - but it sure did flavor this meat very nicely. I wouldn't hesitate to make this recipe again. Served the sandwiches with chips, 'Green Pea Salad with Cheddar Cheese' from AR, chips, veggies and dip and everyone enjoyed their meal.
This was so easy to make and it turned out tender and moist. It makes a ton so I had a freeze some, which will be handy for a later time.
family loved it

This is a huge hit every time I make it. Depending on which beer I have, I also add a squeeze of fresh orange juice. I use less bbq sauce and serve the rest of the sauce on the side because i'm not a huge fan of too much bbq sauce.

Super easy! I followed directions, because they were so simple. Many times, I adjust, but this seemed like a winner.

Put it on before fixing Sunday breakfast (Dutch Babies), and this was ready to turn down and let cook, while we attended church and lunch out. Great Sunday meal. And leftovers for lunches this week!

This was great and all my co-workers and family agreed. I made no changes and it is now my go-to recipe for pulled pork. I still will smoke a pork butt occasionally but for easy overnight pulled pork, this is very good.
this was a little more work than some slow cooker pulled porks. That was due to the draining, cleaning and starting it back up. It was very good though. Work the extra steps.
I used a little less barbeque sauce, and put back some of the liquid I drained to make more moist. Yummy!!!
